articles.headline: In Honduras, a Spiritual and Political Awakening for Tim Kaine
articles.snippet: The vice-presidential nominee’s volunteer work in Central America more than 30 years ago, a time of “intrigue and suspicion” in the region, has informed his career.
articles.abstract: The vice-presidential nominee’s volunteer work in Central America more than 30 years ago, a time of “intrigue and suspicion” in the region, has informed his career.
articles.lead_paragraph: In September 1980, as violence and civil war erupted throughout Central America, a quiet American left Harvard Law School to volunteer with Jesuit missionaries in northern Honduras.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Papers Offer Closer Look at Hillary Clinton Email Inquiry
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton was questioned about her use of a private email system to discuss drone strikes and allowing aides to destroy correspondence.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton was questioned about her use of a private email system to discuss drone strikes and allowing aides to destroy correspondence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. officials questioned Hillary Clinton extensively about her judgment in using her private email system to discuss classified drone strikes and in allowing aides to destroy large numbers of emails, before ultimately deciding she should not face criminal charges, according to investigative documents released Friday.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: How Spy Tech Firms Let Governments See Everything on a Smartphone
articles.snippet: The NSO Group sells expensive surveillance tools for criminal and terrorism inquiries, but critics say they are also used to track journalists and rights activists.
articles.abstract: The NSO Group sells expensive surveillance tools for criminal and terrorism inquiries, but critics say they are also used to track journalists and rights activists.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Want to invisibly spy on 10 iPhone owners without their knowledge? Gather their every keystroke, sound, message and location? That will cost you $650,000, plus a $500,000 setup fee with an Israeli outfit called the NSO Group. You can spy on more people if you would like — just check out the company’s price list.

articles.headline: Tensions Deepen Between Donald Trump and R.N.C.
articles.snippet: The fiery tone of Mr. Trump’s speech on immigration tore a painful new wound in his relationship with the Republican National Committee.
articles.abstract: The fiery tone of Mr. Trump’s speech on immigration tore a painful new wound in his relationship with the Republican National Committee.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee had high hopes that Donald J. Trump would deliver a compassionate and measured speech about immigration on Wednesday, and prepared to lavish praise on the candidate on the party’s Twitter account.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Goodbye, Ivory Tower. Hello, Silicon Valley Candy Store.
articles.snippet: The promise of big data and big paychecks is drawing some of academia’s top economists to study consumer behavior for tech companies like Airbnb, Amazon and Uber.
articles.abstract: The promise of big data and big paychecks is drawing some of academia’s top economists to study consumer behavior for tech companies like Airbnb, Amazon and Uber.
articles.lead_paragraph: For eight years, Peter Coles had an economist’s dream job at Harvard Business School.

articles.headline: Venture Communism: How China Is Building a Start-Up Boom
articles.snippet: The Chinese government is lavishing benefits like free rent and cash handouts on homegrown start-ups in an effort to move beyond the factory floor.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government is lavishing benefits like free rent and cash handouts on homegrown start-ups in an effort to move beyond the factory floor.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — In Dream Town, a collection of boxy office buildings on the gritty edge of this historic city, one tiny company is developing a portable 3-D printer. Another takes orders for traditional Chinese massages by smartphone. They are just two of the 710 start-ups being nurtured here.

articles.headline: Rare Harmony as China and U.S. Commit to Climate Deal
articles.snippet: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China formally committed to the Paris climate agreement at a time of increasingly discordant relations between their nations.
articles.abstract: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China formally committed to the Paris climate agreement at a time of increasingly discordant relations between their nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China formally committed the world’s two largest economies to the Paris climate agreement here on Saturday, cementing their partnership on climate change and offering a rare display of harmony in a relationship that has become increasingly discordant.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Where Has Hillary Clinton Been? Ask the Ultrarich
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s second presidential bid seems to amount to a series of high-dollar fund-raisers with public appearances added to the schedule when they can be fit in.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s second presidential bid seems to amount to a series of high-dollar fund-raisers with public appearances added to the schedule when they can be fit in.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a private fund-raiser Tuesday night at a waterfront Hamptons estate, Hillary Clinton danced alongside Jimmy Buffett, Jon Bon Jovi and Paul McCartney, and joined in a singalong finale to “Hey Jude.”
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Israel Seeking Police Recruits: Eager, and Arab
articles.snippet: An initiative to increase diversity in the national force is seen as an effort to ease deep-rooted tension between officers and Arab citizens.
articles.abstract: An initiative to increase diversity in the national force is seen as an effort to ease deep-rooted tension between officers and Arab citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIRYAT ATTA, Israel — The roll call was startling for a class preparing to take Israel’s police academy exam: Mohammad Hreib, Ghadeer Ghadeer, Munis Huwari and Arafat Hassanein, dressed like a hipster and named after the Palestinian leader, whom most Israeli Jews view as a terrorist.

articles.headline: A Ranger, a Field of Wildflowers and the Retelling of Flight 93
articles.snippet: The task of recounting what happened to the jetliner on Sept. 11, 2001, falls to Robert Franz at what is now a national park in Pennsylvania. The emotions are never far away.
articles.abstract: The task of recounting what happened to the jetliner on Sept. 11, 2001, falls to Robert Franz at what is now a national park in Pennsylvania. The emotions are never far away.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANKSVILLE, Pa. — Just another Thursday, and the morning mix includes leather-vested bikers from New Jersey, Amish visitors from Pennsylvania and a few children adjusting to a park not intended for play. They settle onto benches for the 11 o’clock retelling.

articles.headline: Seeking Support and Invoking Faith, Donald Trump Visits a Black Church for the First Time
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump expressed empathy with African-Americans, but did not address what has made him so unpopular with them, like his real estate company’s discriminating against black tenants.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump expressed empathy with African-Americans, but did not address what has made him so unpopular with them, like his real estate company’s discriminating against black tenants.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Donald J. Trump, who has campaigned for president as a blunt provocateur, dismissing complaints of racial insensitivity as political correctness, took an uncharacteristic step on Saturday: He visited a black church for the first time and tried to blend in.
articles.byline: By Yamiche Alcindor and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: U.S. Presses for Truce in Syria, With Its Larger Policy on Pause
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is engaged in an increasingly desperate effort to broker a deal with Russia for a cease-fire that would halt bombing on Aleppo.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is engaged in an increasingly desperate effort to broker a deal with Russia for a cease-fire that would halt bombing on Aleppo.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — The image of a 5-year-old Syrian boy, dazed and bloodied after being rescued from an airstrike on rebel-held Aleppo, reverberated around the world last month, a harrowing reminder that five years after civil war broke out there, Syria remains a charnel house.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Hollywood’s Summer of Extremes: Megahits, Superflops and Little Else
articles.snippet: As the industry searches for answers, some point to the loss of an underappreciated figure: the ticket buyer who treks to the theater more for the experience than for the movie itself.
articles.abstract: As the industry searches for answers, some point to the loss of an underappreciated figure: the ticket buyer who treks to the theater more for the experience than for the movie itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sequel fatigue does not fully explain it. Nor does an overload of mega-budget event movies. A spate of terrible films? Yes, but that’s not entirely the explanation, either.

articles.headline: ‘Rolling Coal’ in Diesel Trucks, to Rebel and Provoke
articles.snippet: “Coal rollers” alter their diesel trucks so they spew thick black smoke, sometimes in the direction of joggers, cyclists and hybrid cars.
articles.abstract: “Coal rollers” alter their diesel trucks so they spew thick black smoke, sometimes in the direction of joggers, cyclists and hybrid cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTROSE, Colo. — There is a new menace on America’s roads: diesel truck drivers who soup up their engines and remove their emissions controls to “roll coal,” or belch black smoke, at pedestrians, cyclists and unsuspecting Prius drivers.

articles.headline: Young Blacks Voice Skepticism on Hillary Clinton, Worrying Democrats
articles.snippet: The lack of enthusiasm, and in some cases outright resistance, is rooted in a deep discomfort with the establishment that they believe Mrs. Clinton represents.
articles.abstract: The lack of enthusiasm, and in some cases outright resistance, is rooted in a deep discomfort with the establishment that they believe Mrs. Clinton represents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a handful of liberal advocacy organizations convened a series of focus groups with young black voters last month, the assessments of Donald J. Trump were predictably unsparing.

articles.headline: Yes, the News Can Survive the Newspaper
articles.snippet: As newspapers fade from the scene, there has been no certainty that the best services that newspapers provide would live on.
articles.abstract: As newspapers fade from the scene, there has been no certainty that the best services that newspapers provide would live on.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day many decades hence, when your grandchildren ask you, “Grandma, what was a newspaper?” you can direct them back to Wednesday, Sept. 7, 2016. Because it may well go down as the day the American newspaper as we’ve known it moved out of intensive care and into the palliative wing on its way to the Great Beyond.

articles.headline: No Sailors Needed: Robot Sailboats Scour the Oceans for Data
articles.snippet: Richard Jenkins created Saildrone’s autonomous boats to assess fish populations, study the oceans and more, but his grander vision concerns climate change.
articles.abstract: Richard Jenkins created Saildrone’s autonomous boats to assess fish populations, study the oceans and more, but his grander vision concerns climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALAMEDA, Calif. — Two robotic sailboats trace lawn-mower-style paths across the violent surface of the Bering Sea, off the coast of Alaska. The boats are counting fish — pollock, to be specific — with a fancy version of the fish finder sonar you’d find on a bass fishing boat.

articles.headline: Kolkata Testifies to the Grace of Mother Teresa, Its New Saint
articles.snippet: In an Indian city that has expressed ambivalence about the work of a missionary who made it her home, praise carried the day of her canonization by Pope Francis.
articles.abstract: In an Indian city that has expressed ambivalence about the work of a missionary who made it her home, praise carried the day of her canonization by Pope Francis.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — When Mother Teresa’s canonization took place on Sunday, a battered-looking audience gathered in front of a screen some 4,500 miles east of St. Peter’s Square: men with caved-in chests, weeping sores wrapped in gauze, extremities missing entirely, legs so thin you could encircle them with a finger and thumb.

articles.headline: How Uber Drivers Decide How Long to Work
articles.snippet: Many new drivers quit early on days when their hourly wage is high but work longer when it is low, the opposite of what economic rationality would seem to dictate.
articles.abstract: Many new drivers quit early on days when their hourly wage is high but work longer when it is low, the opposite of what economic rationality would seem to dictate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ride-hailing company Uber is best known for upending the taxi industry. Now it may be making waves in the economics profession as well.

articles.headline: SpaceX’s Explosion Reverberates Across Space, Satellite and Telecom Industries
articles.snippet: Last week’s setback is raising new questions about the private space launch company that has risen rapidly by offering lower costs and promising accelerated schedules.
articles.abstract: Last week’s setback is raising new questions about the private space launch company that has risen rapidly by offering lower costs and promising accelerated schedules.
articles.lead_paragraph: The explosion of a SpaceX rocket last Thursday will have an impact across the space industry, far beyond the losses on the launchpad at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

articles.headline: Will the New Apple iPhone Have a Headphone Jack? Rumormongers Say It Won’t
articles.snippet: Apple is expected to unveil the latest model on Wednesday, but if it is indeed missing this basic feature, devotees may be left disenchanted.
articles.abstract: Apple is expected to unveil the latest model on Wednesday, but if it is indeed missing this basic feature, devotees may be left disenchanted.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If Apple had its way, this week would play out like Christmas for 5-year-olds. First, unbelievable anticipation. Then, great surprise. At the end, immense satisfaction.

articles.headline: On Labor Day, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Begin a Final Sprint
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton returned to the trail on Monday after a summer of fund-raising, while Mr. Trump went to Ohio to begin a week of swing-state campaigning.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton returned to the trail on Monday after a summer of fund-raising, while Mr. Trump went to Ohio to begin a week of swing-state campaigning.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump ran virtually parallel campaigns on Monday as they geared up for the final stretch of the presidential race. She made nice with the news media by opening up her campaign plane and chatting with reporters. He followed suit, inviting a smaller group of reporters onto his plane and answering questions during the 30-minute flight.

articles.headline: ‘I’ve Become a Racist’: Migrant Wave Unleashes Danish Tensions Over Identity
articles.snippet: The thousands of Muslim asylum seekers pouring into Denmark have spawned a backlash, and questions over whether the country has a latent racial hostility at its core.
articles.abstract: The thousands of Muslim asylum seekers pouring into Denmark have spawned a backlash, and questions over whether the country has a latent racial hostility at its core.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAARNBY, Denmark — Johnny Christensen, a stout and silver-whiskered retired bank employee, always thought of himself as sympathetic to people fleeing war and welcoming to immigrants. But after more than 36,000 mostly Muslim asylum seekers poured into Denmark over the past two years, Mr. Christensen, 65, said, “I’ve become a racist.”
